instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..

threads.message:
[B]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead[/B]
the client said it have liquid damage but i can't see any corrosion 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13.7V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 0V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0.00v

<SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.424v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.420v

<CHIP>U7890</CHIP>:

1 <SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_REQ</SIGNAL> - 0,33v
2 <SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> - 0,09v
4 <SIGNAL>PM_EN_PVXS5</SIGNAL> - 0,00v
6 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3,42v


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_PMIC</SIGNAL>, 13v0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL>, 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP5V_LDO5V</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>PMIC_SHUTDOWN_L</SIGNAL>. 3.3

 i already replaced the PMIC

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead
threads.message:
Inspect <RESISTOR>R7828</RESISTOR>/29; as per case, only one is used.
Check <SIGNAL>PPBUS_PMIC</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL>.
Also check <SIGNAL>PP1V25_VREF</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead
threads.message:
Did you check for short at <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>?

"<RESISTOR>R7828</RESISTOR>/29; ok"
I'm not sure what this means; only one resistor is in place...
